Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A novel clutch mechanism for a more intuitive, stable prosthetic knee
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project lies in helping more amputees walk safely with less effort. There are approximately 800,000 individuals living with a major lower limb amputation, and this number is growing largely due to diabetes. For 50,000 amputees each year who need a new prosthetic knee, two options exist: learn to use a traditional prosthetic knee or attempt to obtain a high-tech, computer-controlled knee. The former require the amputee learn and execute specific technique(s) to walk safely, while the latter do so automatically but cost $30,000 to $100,000 and require physical qualification, greatly limiting their availability. The novel prosthetic knee developed here offers stability automatically, regardless of amputee technique. It prevents buckling while simultaneously allowing the user to walk safely with whatever leg motions the user is able to generate. Since it requires no electronics or power, it is available to all amputees regardless of ability, and at a fraction of the cost of high-tech knees. Amputees will be able to walk farther with less effort, improving health and quality of life, and easing caregiver burden. Additionally, this design could be adapted for use in orthotic, robotic or exoskeletal systems.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to develop and test a novel prosthetic knee. Funding would be used to build prototypes and conduct mechanical, analytical and destructive testing. This testing is necessary to demonstrate that the design is feasible, safe for humans, and deserving of further development with amputees. An independent engineering design review will be obtained, prototypes will then be bench tested for function in a biomechanics lab, and an independent lab will provide destructive testing to prove ultimate strength of the device for comparison against known standards. The anticipated technical results include proof that the device can support the weight of a 300lb person, and quantitative evidence that the device will afford intuitive and universally available stability to amputees through its innovative swing- and stance-phase functionality. This work would advance the knowledge of prosthetics, rehabilitation and bipedal locomotion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Every year in the US, 50,000 people lose a leg above the knee, and that number will double by 2050 largely due to diabetes. To walk again, an amputee will need either a mechanical or microprocessor-controlled (MP) prosthetic knee. Existing mechanical knee stability typically comes from alignment with respect to the ground reaction force (GRF), the amputee’s control of remaining muscles, or a combination. Such knees can be thought of as defaulting to “unstable” or swing mode, and this presents a learning curve to overcome:  the amputee must successfully execute a specific technique at a specific joint and at a specific time to achieve stability. In contrast, MP knees automatically turn “on” the stability control at the appropriate time, and default to stability mode most of the time. While this does yield benefits, MP knees are expensive ($30,000 - $100,000) and Medicare functional levels for amputation are used in prescribing them – meaning amputees must qualify physically to be eligible. As a result, only about 10% of amputees will ever receive an MP knee.

A gap exists in present technology for a knee that provides automatic stability similar to MP knees, yet is a passive mechanical device accessible to all amputees. The Xonotiv Knee provides intuitive and universally available stability (defined as prevention of unwanted flexion when weighted at any angle) with no need for expensive power or electronics and no need for the user to learn and execute particular knee-stabilizing techniques, braking actions, or joint moments. It incorporates a two-way overrunning clutch that defaults to stability mode yet is a low-cost mechanical device. The resulting clutching action makes this device innovative compared to current technology. It offers stability automatically and regardless of alignment, joint angles or GRF locations, all without the hydraulics, pneumatics, or electronics of higher-functional-level prostheses. Taken together, these attributes should improve walking and sit-to-stand performance, and provide stability on uneven ground, particularly for low-ability amputees.

The purpose of this Phase I project was to construct and test several human-scale engineering prototypes as proof of concept of the Xonotiv Knee described above. The research plan consisted of two Key Objectives:  the first sought to prove the prosthetic knee device can support the weight of a person, while the second sought to confirm the innovative stance and swing phase characteristics described above.

The results demonstrate that the Xonotiv knee safely supports the weight of human amputees, and provides intuitive and universally available stability without the need for power, electronics, or specialized user techniques.


Last Modified: 07/30/2019
Modified by: Paul Pomeroy

In contrast, MP knees automatically turn "on" the stability control at the appropriate time, and default to stability mode most of the time.
